questions.question: What is the primary goal of SVM when applied to credit card fraud detection?

answers.b: To classify transactions as fraudulent or legitimate

explanations.b: Correct! SVM is a supervised classifier that separates fraud from genuine transactions.
explanations.c: SVM does not affect processing speed.
explanations.d: Generation of synthetic data is done by other techniques (e.g., SMOTE).

questions.question: In SVM terminology, the data points that define the position of the maximum-margin hyperplane are called:

explanations.c: Correct! Only support vectors influence the final hyperplane and margin.

questions.question: Which kernel is most frequently recommended for real-world credit card fraud detection with SVM?

explanations.c: Correct! RBF is the most popular and usually outperforms others due to its flexibility in modeling complex, localized fraud patterns.

questions.question: Why is accuracy a misleading metric for evaluating fraud detection models?

answers.a: Because fraud rates are extremely low (severe class imbalance)
answers.c: Because accuracy requires balanced classes to be meaningful
answers.d: Because fraud data has no ground truth

explanations.a: Correct! With fraud <0.2%, a model predicting 'always legitimate' achieves >99.8% accuracy but detects zero fraud.

questions.question: What is the main role of the regularization parameter C in soft-margin SVM?

answers.a: To control the shape of the RBF kernel
answers.b: To balance margin maximization versus training error minimization
answers.d: To determine the number of support vectors directly

explanations.b: Correct! Small C → larger margin (more tolerant to errors); large C → fewer errors (risk of overfitting).

questions.question: In highly imbalanced fraud detection problems, which evaluation metric is generally preferred over ROC-AUC?

explanations.b: Correct! PR-AUC focuses on performance on the rare fraud class and is much more informative than ROC-AUC when positive examples are scarce.
